description: Milestones in the musical, horror, science-fiction and more.
text:
Top five films: what's new to streaming services Jacques Demy's all-singing,
all-dancing 1967 follow-up to his famous The Umbrellas of Cherbourg is the
most spectacular and joyful of his films, though not without twinges of
unease. Real-life sisters Catherine Deneuve and Francoise Dorleac star as
twins who find love one weekend when the fair comes to town. Foxtel Now. Made
in 1922 at the height of the German Expressionist movement, F.W. Murnau's
silent version of Dracula casts a stronger spell than any of its successors,
conjuring up an archaic world where the existence of vampires seems wholly
credible. The ratlike Count Orlok, played by Max Schreck, is not the tale's
only grotesque. Kanopy. Based on one of the Marx Brothers' Broadway hits, this
1930 comedy is the nearest thing we have to a record of their legendary stage
performances. The setting is a party thrown by the wealthy Mrs Rittenhouse
(the incomparable Margaret Dumont) - but from the moment Groucho launches into
My Name Is Captain Spaulding you'll forget all about the plot. MUBI. A young
go-getter (Tom Keene) shakes off the Depression blues by becoming the leader
of a farming co-operative in this 1934 drama - an independently financed
passion project for director King Vidor ( The Fountainhead ), epitomising an
attractive, all-American radicalism that transcends distinctions between left
and right. Amazon Prime. Ridley Scott has never equalled the moody magic of
his 1982 science-fiction noir, based on a novel by Philip K. Dick and one of
the genuine pop classics of its era. Harrison Ford is the grumpy private eye
stalking a group of rebellious androids - including Daryl Hannah, Sean Young
and Rutger Hauer - through a rainy, futuristic LA. Netflix.

title: Top five films: what's new to streaming services [Brisbane Times (Australia)]
html: Top five films: what's new to streaming services Jacques Demy's all-singing, all-dancing 1967 follow-up to his famous The Umbrellas of Cherbourg is the most spectacular and joyful of his films, though not without twinges of unease. Real-life sisters Catherine Deneuve and Francoise Dorleac star as twins who find love one weekend when the fair comes to town. Foxtel Now. Made in 1922 at the height of the German Expressionist movement, F.W. Murnau's silent version of Dracula casts a stronger spell than any of its successors, conjuring up an archaic world where the existence of vampires seems wholly credible. The ratlike Count Orlok, played by Max Schreck, is not the tale's only grotesque. Kanopy. Based on one of the Marx Brothers' Broadway hits, this 1930 comedy is the nearest thing we have to a record of their legendary stage performances. The setting is a party thrown by the wealthy Mrs Rittenhouse (the incomparable Margaret Dumont) – but from the moment Groucho launches into My Name Is Captain Spaulding you'll forget all about the plot. MUBI. A young go-getter (Tom Keene) shakes off the Depression blues by becoming the leader of a farming co-operative in this 1934 drama – an independently financed passion project for director King Vidor ( The Fountainhead ), epitomising an attractive, all-American radicalism that transcends distinctions between left and right. Amazon Prime. Ridley Scott has never equalled the moody magic of his 1982 science-fiction noir, based on a novel by Philip K. Dick and one of the genuine pop classics of its era. Harrison Ford is the grumpy private eye stalking a group of rebellious androids – including Daryl Hannah, Sean Young and Rutger Hauer – through a rainy, futuristic LA. Netflix.
